item.title: Conclusions
item.description:
Summary of Findings

Briefly summarize your main findings and what they contribute to understanding your topic.

Limitations

Discuss the limitations of your project. What constraints did you face? What aspects couldn’t be addressed?

  • Data limitations
  • Methodological constraints
  • Scope limitations

Future Research Directions

What questions remain unanswered? How could this work be extended?

  • Future direction 1
  • Future direction 2
  • Future direction 3

Final Thoughts

Conclude with reflections on what this project reveals about your chosen topic.

item.title: References
item.description:
Works Cited

List all sources using a consistent citation format (MLA, APA, Chicago, etc.).

Data Sources

  • [Primary dataset citation with URL and access date]
  • [Secondary dataset citation if applicable]

Scholarly Sources

  • Author Last Name, First Name. Title of Work. Publisher, Year.
  • Author Last Name, First Name. “Article Title.” Journal Name, vol. X, no. X, Year, pp. XX-XX.
  • Author Last Name, First Name. “Web Article Title.” Website Name, Date, URL.

Additional Resources

  • [Any other references, tools, or resources used]

Data Availability

Describe where readers can access the data used in this project.

item.title: Results
item.description:
Overview

This analysis examines two comprehensive datasets of popular music: 500 top songs from the 1960s and 500 top songs from the 2000s. Each dataset includes information about song titles, artists, genres, view counts, and other metadata, allowing for comparative analysis across these two distinct musical eras separated by four decades.

The visualizations below are generated dynamically from the full datasets.

Top Songs by Popularity

The chart below shows the top 10 most viewed songs across both decades, with colors indicating their era (blue for 1960s, red for 2000s).
